description: From Latin Maeander, from Ancient Greek Μαίανδρος (Maíandros) – a river in Asia Minor (present day Turkey) known for its winding course (modern Turkish Menderes).

entries.meaning: (often plural) One of the turns of a winding, crooked, or involved course.
examples: the meanders of an old river, or of the veins and arteries in the body

entries.meaning: (geography) One of a series of regular sinuous curves, bends, loops, turns, or windings in the channel of a river, stream, or other watercourse
examples: See, how the streams advancing to the main, / Through crooked channels draw their crystal train! / While lingering thus they in meanders glide, / They scatter verdant life on either side.

entries.meaning: Synonym of Greek key, a decorative border; fretwork.
(mathematics) A self-avoiding closed curve which intersects a line a number of times.
(possibly obsolete) A path on which the directions, distances, and elevations are noted, as a part of a land survey.

verbs.description: meander (third-person singular simple present meanders, present participle meandering, simple past and past participle meandered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To wind or turn in a course or passage; to be intricate.
examples: The stream meandered through the valley.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To wind, turn, or twist; to make flexuous.
